title: Generate changelog on production publish
description:
### Problem

API Security currently does not produce or have a changelog. This makes it hard for customers, especially offline customers, to understand when they should upgrade to newer versions of API Security. This is also different from other GitLab analyzers, which produce and publish changelogs with their releases.

### Proposal

- Add to our existing production publish job
- Changelogs will not be public yet
- Use GitLabs template as a starting point
  - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/.gitlab/changelog_config.yml
  - Will need some changes, especially with version regex
- API Call: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/repositories.html#add-changelog-data-to-a-changelog-file

epic.title: Align API Security versioning and release process with GitLab

title: Switch to MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH versioning
description:
### Problem

API Security's versioning does not align with the rest of GitLab which uses `MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH` versioning. Differences like this make it confusing for customers when deploying our solutions.

At the time of writing, API Security uses `MAJOR.MINOR.BUILD`. The `MAJOR` and `MINOR` portions are manually incremented. Due to the use of `BUILD`, not all version numbers are released and available to customers.

### Proposal

Capturing rough steps:

1. Stop tagging every build
1. Only tag actual public releases
1. Increment the `MINOR` portion of the version on each public release
1. Change `peach-web.properties` to specify only the major version
1. Update `build/buildtag.sh` to use new logic

epic.title: Align API Security versioning and release process with GitLab

title: Update MR template to include changelog entry check
description:
### Problem

API Security will start using GitLab's changelog generation feature as part of the release process.
This works by taking the commit title for commits that include the `changelog` git-trailer and adding it to the `CHANGELOG.md` file.
As such, the MR review process steps must now include checking for changelog entry and reviewing the commit title.

title: Replace existing project member queries with project namespace members queries - Project members page
description:
Project members are currently fetched through the polymorphic `source` on the `Member` model.

```mermaid
graph TD
  User --- Member
  Member-- source ---Project
  Member-- source ---Namespace
  Namespace-- Is A ---Group
```

In https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/6768 a parallel project membership system was established through the `members.member_namespace_id` column and the addition of the `ProjectNamespace` model. Every `Project` is parented by a `ProjectNamespace` model via the `projects.project_namespace_id` column.

```mermaid
graph TD
  User --- Member
  Member-- member_namespace_id ---Namespace
  Namespace-- Is A ---Group
  Namespace-- Is A ---ProjectNamespace
  ProjectNamespace-- project_namespace_id ---Project
```

This new system aligns our hierarchy so we only have `Namespaces` and not `Namespaces` and `Projects`.

We now need to replace all membership queries using the old polymorphic `source` system, with the new `member_namespace_id` system.

All replacements will need to be behind a feature flag.

## To Do
 In this issue we want to address the way we gather members for the project members page. By creating the new MembersFinder we can leverage the new system and start by making changes in one place. This will also help us uncover any potential problems and gaps before rolling the changes further. 

This change will be behind feature flag. 

### Availability and Testing

- No new E2E tests or updates needed at this time. Since changes will be behind a feature flag, if the MR(s) for these changes updates a feature flag definition file, please review the `ee:instance-parallel` and `ee:instance-parallel-ff-inverse` jobs within `e2e:package-and-test`, which should be triggered automatically. 
- Otherwise, if these changes will be using an existing feature flag, please create a draft MR that includes these changes along with the feature flag definition file set to `default_enabled: true`. This will then trigger the jobs above to E2E test the changes with the FF both on and off (see https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/testing_guide/end_to_end/feature_flags.html#automatic-test-execution-when-a-feature-flag-definition-changes for more details)
- Feel free to ping `@vburton` if there are any questions on E2E test failures.

epic.title: Group minimum role should be Guest for epic relations

title: Group minimum role should be Guest for adding child epic
description:
Currently, in order to [add a child epic to a parent](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/epics/manage_epics.html#add-a-child-epic-to-an-epic), the user must have a minimum role of `Reporter` in the parent epic. Since `Guest` users can view epic data, there is no concern of leaking data by allowing this behavior.

**In this issue, we will change the group minimum role requirements to `Guest`.**

**Note**: The policy `:admin_epic_relation` added in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/106415 should be used to replace `:admin_epic`.

### Tasks

- [x] Update documentation https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/106415
- [x] Update services and endpoints https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/106415
- [x] Update quick actions https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/106558
- [x] Update UI dropdown for epics tree https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/106434



## Docs Support

For issues requiring an update to GitLab docs, please note that this is part of the definition of done for this issue. Please create a separate MR for the docs update related to the MR for the actual change to ensure code reviews are not blocked by TW reviews.

- [x] This issue requires an update to GitLab docs

title: [VSA parity] Support value stream and stage creation for ProjectNamespace
description:
Currently, the `GroupValueStream` and `GroupStage` models can only be associated with a `Group`. To support `ProjectNamespace` we need to change the association definition.

Example (see the association changes in the model files): https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/101361

Additionally:

- Add validation to the models to only accept `Group` and `ProjectNamespace` instances for the associations.
- Rename the `GroupValueStream` and `GroupStage` models (remove the Group prefix). 
- The table name (`group_value_streams`) and the FK column (`group_id`) name can stay as is.
  - Maybe at some point, we will migrate the data to new tables. (could be a tech debt task)
- In the related services (`ValueStreams::CreateService`), rename the `group` parameter to `namespace` (or `parent`)

title: Change how we consume seats in use in the frontend
description:
This is a technical implementation after our investigation in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/361991


## Technical details

We need to replace [`this.totalSeatsInUse` method](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d1aba473/ee/app/assets/javascripts/usage_quotas/seats/components/subscription_seats.vue#L149-153) with the use of `this.total`.

We want to update specs in `subscription_seats_spec.js` to cover the changes.

## Steps to reproduce


1. Go to any **Paid** group
2. Go to `Settings > Usage Quotas > Seats tab` (`http://gdk.test:3000/groups/< group-id >/-/usage_quotas#seats-quota-tab`)
3. Take note of the seats the **paid** group is using
4. Then go to `Group information > Members` (`http://gdk.test:3000/groups/< group-id >/-/group_members`)
5. Add a new Member
6. Go back to the `Usage Quotas` page (`http://gdk.test:3000/groups/< group-id >/-/usage_quotas#seats-quota-tab`)
6. Observe the cards numbers don't change
6. After the code change described above, we'll have the real numbers for `Seats in use / Seats in subscription`

If you want to see the numbers for **Max seats used** and **Seats owed** to update, you'll need to go to `rails console`:

```
subscription = Group.find(108).gitlab_subscription
subscription.refresh_seat_attributes!
subscription.save!
```


| Before code change | After code change | After script above (and adding more members)
| ------ | ------ | -- |
| ![before_code_change](/uploads/300484356b9db3da855b089078850a94/before_code_change.png) | ![after_code_change](/uploads/3b39cea4938b108691169ae158adca03/after_code_change.png) | ![After_sript_and_over_seats](/uploads/f92f9b4f4c495b8bb47f70385d59a2ce/After_sript_and_over_seats.png)  |

---

**MR implementing this issue**: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/103817

title: Add service ping context to redis_hll_counters.epics_usage.epics_usage_total_unique_counts_monthly
description:
## Background

There are two Product Intelligence data tracking systems in place at GitLab: [Service Ping](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/service_ping/) and [Snowplow](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/) event tracking. Recently there was effort undertaken by ~"group::product intelligence" to mirror some of data reported by Service Ping with Snowplow event tracking to help GitLab members better understand wider community interactions with GitLab, and make better decision how to develop and improve it. 
 
## Problem

The snowplow events labeled with:
- `redis_hll_counters.epics_usage.epics_usage_total_unique_counts_monthly`
does not pass the required [context](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/schemas.html#gitlab_service_ping) yet to be usable for the data team.

## Desired Outcome

Snowplow event custom context (see [documentation](https://docs.snowplow.io/docs/understanding-your-pipeline/canonical-event/#contexts) about what context are) as defined [here](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/schemas.html#gitlab_service_ping) is passed to the event.

## Hints

First locate all places where `redis_hll_counters.epics_usage.epics_usage_total_unique_counts_monthly` is emitted (hint: see how Snowplow [frontend](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/implementation.html#implement-data-attribute-tracking) and [backend](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/implementation.html#implement-ruby-backend-tracking) tracking is implemented at GitLab

Identify what Service Ping RedisHll events were mirrored for example at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/lib/gitlab/usage_data_counters/epic_activity_unique_counter.rb#L215

```ruby
        def track_linked_epic_with_type_is_blocked_by_removed(author:, namespace:)
          track_snowplow_action(EPIC_BLOCKED_REMOVED, author, namespace)
          track_unique_action(EPIC_BLOCKED_REMOVED, author)
        end

```
Via `EPIC_BLOCKED_REMOVED` constant `g_project_management_epic_blocked_removed` event is tracked

Fill out required context with eg: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/tracking/service_ping_context.rb for backend events

```ruby
      Gitlab::Tracking.event(
        self.class.to_s,
        name,
        namespace: tracking_namespace_source,
        user: current_user,
        context: [Gitlab::Tracking::ServicePingContext.new(data_source: :redis_hll, event: name).to_context]
      )
``` 

Or create context manually for front end events eg: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/projects/pipelines/charts/components/app.vue#L85

```vue

        this.track('click_tab', {
          label: SNOWPLOW_LABEL,
          context: {
            schema: SNOWPLOW_SCHEMA,
            data: {
              event_name: event,
              data_source: SNOWPLOW_DATA_SOURCE,
            },
          },
        });
```

Test you changes with [Snowplow Micro](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/implementation.html#snowplow-micro) included in gdk

title: Add service ping context to redis_hll_counters.ecosystem.ecosystem_total_unique_counts_monthly
description:
## Background

There are two Product Intelligence data tracking systems in place at GitLab: [Service Ping](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/service_ping/) and [Snowplow](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/) event tracking. Recently there was effort undertaken by ~"group::product intelligence" to mirror some of data reported by Service Ping with Snowplow event tracking to help GitLab members better understand wider community interactions with GitLab, and make better decision how to develop and improve it. 
 
## Problem

The snowplow events labeled with:
- `redis_hll_counters.ecosystem.ecosystem_total_unique_counts_monthly`
does not pass the required [context](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/schemas.html#gitlab_service_ping) yet to be usable for the data team.

## Desired Outcome

Snowplow event custom context (see [documentation](https://docs.snowplow.io/docs/understanding-your-pipeline/canonical-event/#contexts) about what context are) as defined [here](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/schemas.html#gitlab_service_ping) is passed to the event.

## Implementation Guide

First locate all places where `redis_hll_counters.ecosystem.ecosystem_total_unique_counts_monthly` is emitted (hint: see how Snowplow [frontend](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/implementation.html#implement-data-attribute-tracking) and [backend](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/implementation.html#implement-ruby-backend-tracking) tracking is implemented at GitLab

Identify what Service Ping RedisHll events were mirrored for example at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/integrations/base_slack_notification.rb#L45

```ruby
    def log_usage(event, user_id)
      return unless user_id

      return unless SUPPORTED_EVENTS_FOR_USAGE_LOG.include?(event)

      key = "#{metrics_key_prefix}_#{event}_notification"

      Gitlab::UsageDataCounters::HLLRedisCounter.track_event(key, values: user_id)
....
```
Via `key` variable stores tracked event

Fill out required context with eg: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/tracking/service_ping_context.rb for backend events

```ruby
      Gitlab::Tracking.event(
        self.class.to_s,
        name,
        namespace: tracking_namespace_source,
        user: current_user,
        context: [Gitlab::Tracking::ServicePingContext.new(data_source: :redis_hll, event: name).to_context]
      )
``` 

Or create context manually for front end events eg: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/projects/pipelines/charts/components/app.vue#L85

```vue

        this.track('click_tab', {
          label: SNOWPLOW_LABEL,
          context: {
            schema: SNOWPLOW_SCHEMA,
            data: {
              event_name: event,
              data_source: SNOWPLOW_DATA_SOURCE,
            },
          },
        });
```

Test you changes with [Snowplow Micro](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/implementation.html#snowplow-micro) included in gdk

Make sure that all events from metric yaml definition [file](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/config/metrics/counts_28d/20210216184957_ecosystem_total_unique_counts_monthly.yml#L18) has been tracked with snowplow context

Example MR that achieves similar result for different event for reference: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/103534/diffs

In case of questions head to [`#g_product_intelligence` slack channel](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CL3A7GFPF) or tag `@gitlab-org/analytics-section/product-intelligence/engineers` in comment in this issue

## Testing

Update related tests

title: Disable ZAP passive checks for browser-based scans
description:
### Problem

ZAP passive checks run when DAST runs a browser-based scan. These are of little value as important passive checks have been replaced by checks written by the GitLab vulnerability research team.

This creates extra noise for customers, as vulnerabilities are created for these findings. It makes scans run longer than necessary. Turning off passive scans would give DAST engineers more options when they make architectural design decisions.

### Proposal

All ZAP passive checks are disabled when running a browser-based scan. For non browser-based scans, passive checks should remain enabled.

### Implementation plan

- [x] If it is a browser-based scan:
  - [x] Find all passive check IDs `ZAProxy._all_passive_scanner_ids`
  - [x] Exclude all passive check IDs `ZAProxy.exclude_rules`
- [x] Add a changelog entry
- [x] Update end-to-end tests

title: Webhook encrypted tokens - Error testing when parts of the domain is masked
description:
1. Create a webhook that masks part of the domain. For example, when using `https://example.com/hello` and mask `example.com` as `domain`.
2. Test the webhook with any event.
3. See an error that looks like below:
![Webhook_mask_URL_error](/uploads/720b5725cb92ea57e00fcd49a5ed1f02/Webhook_mask_URL_error.png)

## Proposal

Steps:
1. Add a new column to the `web_hook_logs` table (e.g. `url_hash`), which stores a SHA1 hash of the interpolated hook URL at the time of execution
2. Update the `TestHooks` services with the following:
    - get the `log.hook.interpolated_url`, hash it and compare it to the stored hash
    - if the same, then retry with the value of `log.hook.interpolated_url`
    - if different, error with a message that the URL has changed, and this log entry cannot be retried
3. Remove the `web_hook_logs.url` column

title: /gitlab help slash command can fail with dispatch_failed
description:
**Note** screen captures are from the development Slack app.

### Summary

For some users, the `/gitlab help` slash command can repeatedly fail with a `dispatch_failed` error message returned to the user in Slack. This happens unless they have connected their GitLab account, which they can still do by using other slash commands.

![image](/uploads/7b01cf7c32bd1dfc3a57943e85e2c8c7/image.png)

## Workaround

People can use any other slash commands to be prompted to connect their GitLab account.

For example, using a project that has a GitLab for Slack app integration for the workspace: 

```
/gitlab <project full path> issue show 1
```

It will prompt you to connect your account:

![image](/uploads/bcc8c5d62c741ec1f763590eb790ef22/image.png)

Click `connect your GitLab account` to connect your account.

### Steps to reproduce

First either ensure you have no "chat name" records https://gitlab.com/-/profile/chat_names, or do this on a fresh GitPod instance.

```
/gitlab help
```

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

You see a `dispatch_failed` error.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The help should display.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

This is a stack trace of the error:

```
NoMethodError (undefined method `user' for nil:NilClass
Did you mean?  super):
  /workspace/gitlab/lib/gitlab/slash_commands/base_command.rb:40:in `initialize'
  /workspace/gitlab/ee/app/services/slash_commands/global_slack_handler.rb:26:in `new'
  /workspace/gitlab/ee/app/services/slash_commands/global_slack_handler.rb:26:in `trigger'
  /workspace/gitlab/ee/lib/ee/api/integrations.rb:13:in `block (2 levels) in <module:Integrations>'
```

### Possible fixes

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->

title: Webhook secret tokens can be leaked by maintainer changing URL
description:
**[HackerOne report #1757999](https://hackerone.com/reports/1757999)** by `joaxcar` on 2022-11-01, assigned to @greg:

[Report](#report) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce) | [Imported issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/383113)

## Report

Imported from h1: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/383113

#### Summary

Since issue [#359989 (closed)](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/359989) was merged, webhook secrets are now hidden for maintainers of a project after they are saved. The UI and API gives no way of retrieving the secret after configuration.

However, a maintainer with access to the project webhook settings could change the webhook URL to a different endpoint and extract the secret token via the request sent to that endpoint. 

#### Impact

Secret webhook tokens are discoverable to project maintainers who change the webhook URL.

#### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Secret token value is retained, *not* reset upon changing the webhook URL.

#### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Secret token will be reset and not retained after changing a webhook URL.

#### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

#### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

## How To Reproduce

Please add [reproducibility information](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/security/#reproducibility-on-security-issues) to this section:

1. Create a new project
2. Go to https://gitlab.com/GROUP/PROJECT/-/hooks and configure a webhook. Make sure you also add a secret token.
3. Click save
4. Invite another user to the project as a maintainer
5. Log into GitLab as the newly-appointed maintainer
6. Go to the project hooks as this user https://gitlab.com/GROUP/PROJECT/-/hooks 
7. Modify webhook URL to point to an endpoint that can be used to sniff/extract the secret token (webhook.site)
8. Test the webhook
9. Get secret token from request header sent to the new endpoint
10. (Optional) Change webhook URL back to original URL to restore functionality and reduce likelihook of detection


Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/381895

title: [Feature flag] Geo: Rollout Replicate Dependency Proxy Manifests
description:
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/376071

## Summary

This issue is to roll out Dependency Proxy Manifests replication on production,
that is currently behind the `geo_dependency_proxy_manifest_replication` feature flag.



## Owners

- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_geo`
- Best individual to reach out to: Valery Sizov
- PM: Juan Silva

- Team: Geo team
## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

Manifests have to be replicated to a secondary

### When is the feature viable?

When Geo is enabled and when the Dependency Proxy feature is used

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Dependency Proxy Manifests can not be replicated. Or replication status in the admin area can be shown with errors.


### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

Admin Geo section

## Rollout Steps

- [x] Test replication and verification of Dependency Proxy Manifests on a non-GDK-deployment. For example, using GitLab Environment Toolkit

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [x] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for a review and merge it.
    - [x] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [x] Consider cleaning up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel. Otherwise, these settings may override the default enabled.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete geo_dependency_proxy_manifest_replication --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [x] Close https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/376071 to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [x] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [x] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `geo_dependency_proxy_manifest_replication`".
    - [x] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [x] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce the complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [x] Close [the feature issue][main-issue] to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete geo_dependency_proxy_manifest_replication --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set geo_dependency_proxy_manifest_replication false
```

title: Document workaround for when backup cannot be restored with `pg_stat_statements` enabled

### Problem to solve

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/351071 we have investigated why sometimes restoring from a backup fails due to `pg_stat_statements` enabled being enabled.

title: 403 error when HEAD API request for generic packages with AWS as object storage and `proxy_download=false`
description:
### Summary In !27612 a bug was fixed to allow Gradle to issue HEAD requests for Maven packages stored in the package registry on AWS S3 storage, and with `proxy_download` disabled. The problem was related to the way the redirects generated by GitLab to S3 were signed. This issue highlights that the same issue exists for generic packages (and possibly other package types) and that the same functionality should be available to support the use of a HEAD request to obtain key metadata values (e.g. size, etag) to assist with detecting when packages are updated in the registry. Note that when `proxy_download` is enabled GitLab retrieves the details from S3 and passes them back to the requesting client, and there is no problem. But enabling this setting is not always an option for customers due to the impact it has on server load and network traffic and associated costs. GET requests to retrieve the package file work OK whether `proxy_download` is enabled or not. This issue was reported by a self-managed Premium customer ([ZD internal link](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/342316)). Note that there is currently an [open issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/381504) relating to HEAD requests for Maven projects no longer working in 15.4. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Configure the GitLab package registry to store package files in an S3 bucket. 1. Set `gitlab_rails['object_store']['proxy_download'] = false` in GitLab to disable proxying of requests to object storage. Doing this means a GitLab will return a redirect response to the client directing it to retrieve the package file from S3 directly, with temporary credentials. 1. Publish package file as a generic package to the GitLab package registry, e.g.: ``` curl --header "PRIVATE-TOKEN: " --upload-file packagefile.pkg "https://gitlab.example.com/api/v4/projects/24/packages/generic/my_package/0.0.1/packagefile.pkg" ``` 1. Run the following HEAD command via curl: ``` curl -L --head --header "PRIVATE-TOKEN: " "https://gitlab.example.com/api/v4/projects/24/packages/generic/my_package/0.0.1/pkgfile.pkg ``` 1. Observe that a redirect to AWS S3 is received from GitLab and the response to that is a 403 error, e.g.: ``` HTTP/1.1 302 Found Server: nginx Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2022 08:19:21 GMT Content-Type: text/plain Content-Length: 518 Connection: keep-alive Cache-Control: no-cache Location: https://ubuntu-2004-15-4-3-registry.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/2c/62/2c624232cdd221771294dfbb310aca000a0df6ac8b66b696d90ef06fdefb64a3/packages/24/files/9/pkgfile.pkg?X-Amz-Expires=600&X-Amz-Date=20221110T081921Z&X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX%2F20221110%2Fap-southeast-2%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&X-Amz-Signature=7bea0ecc102039ddceba7ab9d49dbb39b2a685e7763d85e4aaa9ad0b4a700111 Vary: Origin X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN X-Request-Id: 01GHG9YGSDPSBG50S2MRED19G0 X-Runtime: 0.084538 Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=63072000 Referrer-Policy: strict-origin-when-cross-origin HTTP/1.1 403 Forbidden x-amz-request-id: 2MZW7GXKM1M87KPW x-amz-id-2: os5Gro+WgqLmqhW4qDVstAmUkZI1y2NWjUZM0wZ73M40DGWA/SGkoEP6RAKJZRCcHuRLl4ySpQg= Content-Type: application/xml Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2022 08:09:58 GMT Server: AmazonS3 ``` ### Example Project ### What is the current *bug* behavior? HEAD requests receive a 403 error from AWS S3 when using the redirect link supplied by GitLab. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? HEAD requests should return the expected data and a 200 code. ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes

title: Deprecate dedicated requirement object (legacy) IID in GraphQL API
description:
See https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/9203#note_1170193578 for a breakdown.

After we have support of both dedicated requirement IID and work item IID to refer to a requirement, we can begin deprecating dedicated requirement object references (e.g. IIDs) and supporting customers that use them to move across to use work item IIDs.

I think once we've removed the legacy Requirement IID, we can then proceed with using the Work Item GraphQL query instead of the Requirements filter, and then https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/345308+. It also means we maybe don't have to add legacy IID support to Work Items API.

GraphQL filtering will involve using `deprecated:` parameter to the filtration argument. The list itself could possibly put a `DEPRECATED` sort of warning next to the old IID? See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/382141

title: Remove in-product survey link about migrating to the Package Registry
description:
## Context
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/372960 we added a banner to the Package Registry to prompt users to answer a survey:

![image](/uploads/da36e0e270d66e6a504fb722d24b9191/image.png)

We've since had 600+ responses. I propose we remove this banner in milestone 15.7. That will mean the banner has been shown for about 1 month.

## Implementation guide

Revert changes made in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/100784+

title: Rollout FF enable_environments_search_within_folder
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

<!--
Set the main issue link: The main issue is the one that describes the problem to solve,
the one this feature flag is being added for. For example:

[main-issue]: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/123456
-->

[main-issue]: MAIN-ISSUE-LINK

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [search environments names within folder](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/373850) on production,
that is currently behind the `enable_environments_search_within_folder` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: release
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#s_release`
- Best individual to reach out to: @bala.kumar 
- PM: @cbalane 

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

With the FF rollouts, users should be able to search environments within folder.

### When is the feature viable?

<!-- What are the settings we need to configure in order to have this feature viable? -->

<!-- 
Example below:
 
1. Enable service ping collection
   `ApplicationSetting.first.update(usage_ping_enabled: true)`
-->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

If the queries involved is taking longer time, the request can timeout.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

- https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/f821afd0-6b01-11ed-9f43-e3784d7fe3ca
- https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/9afdcdd0-6b00-11ed-85ed-e7557b0a598c

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

Can watch-out for 5xx in the above logs link

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status f6ab943eb4eb9ac222104875826a739e42569b2c`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set enable_environments_search_within_folder true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status f6ab943eb4eb9ac222104875826a739e42569b2c`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com enable_environments_search_within_folder true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org,gitlab-com enable_environments_search_within_folder true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> enable_environments_search_within_folder true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [x] Set a milestone to the rollout issue to signal for enabling and removing the feature flag when it is stable.
- [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Leave a comment on [the feature issue][main-issue] announcing estimated time when this feature flag will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [ ] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set enable_environments_search_within_folder <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set enable_environments_search_within_folder <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set enable_environments_search_within_folder true`
- [x] Leave a comment on [the feature issue][main-issue] announcing that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [x] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [x] Consider cleaning up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel. Otherwise these settings may override the default enabled.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete enable_environments_search_within_folder --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [x] Close [the feature issue][main-issue] to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [x] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [x] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `enable_environments_search_within_folder`".
    - [x] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [x] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [x] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `enable_environments_search_within_folder` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue][main-issue] to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete enable_environments_search_within_folder --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set enable_environments_search_within_folder false
```

In this scenario, labels must be related to it, for example; ~"type::feature", ~"type::bug" or ~"type::maintenance".
Please use /copy_metadata to copy the labels from the issue you're rolling out. -->

title: Exec Dashboards: Add sparkline to the metrics comparative table
description:
### Overview

Once the [Exec Dashboards MVC](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370887) will be completed, we need to add sparklines to help our users quickly understand the metrics performance over time. 


### [Problem to solve](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370887#problem-to-solve)
### User experience goal

1. Quickly identify patterns in metrics trends (seasonal changes or other cycles).
2. Quickly compare metrics improvement over time.

### Proposal 

1. Add sparklines line charts for each metrics.
1. The sparkline will display the metrics value trends (not change rate %).
2. The sparkline will display the past six months data, aggregated monthly.
1. Data order from left to right.
1. Y-Axis start at 0.
2. To improve performance please consider lazy loading of the sparklines. 
3. Out of scope for this issue - highlight the sparklines maximum and minimum values in a different color.

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `ci_assign_job_token_on_scheduling`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

<!--
Set the main issue link: The main issue is the one that describes the problem to solve,
the one this feature flag is being added for. For example:

[main-issue]: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/123456
-->

[main-issue]: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/103377

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the feature][main-issue] on production,
that is currently behind the `ci_assign_job_token_on_scheduling` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::pipeline execution" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_pipeline_execution`
- Best individual to reach out to: `@mbobin`
- PM: `@jheimbuck_gl` 

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

Pipeline creation should be faster!

### When is the feature viable?

<!-- What are the settings we need to configure in order to have this feature viable? -->

<!-- 
Example below:
 
1. Enable service ping collection
   `ApplicationSetting.first.update(usage_ping_enabled: true)`
-->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

problems with job token authentication, missing tokens.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

 - [API error rate](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/stage-groups-pipeline_execution/stage-groups-pipeline-execution-group-dashboard?orgId=1&from=1667273280000&to=1667294939999&viewPanel=25)
 - [Web error rate](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/stage-groups-pipeline_execution/stage-groups-pipeline-execution-group-dashboard?orgId=1&from=1667273280000&to=1667294939999&viewPanel=26)
 - [Sidekiq error rate](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/stage-groups-pipeline_execution/stage-groups-pipeline-execution-group-dashboard?orgId=1&from=1667273340000&to=1667294999999&viewPanel=41)
 - [Duration of the builds queue retrieval using the big query SQL](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/stage-groups-pipeline_execution/stage-groups-pipeline-execution-group-dashboard?orgId=1&from=1667273400000&to=1667295059999&viewPanel=2762861754)

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

- https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_assign_job_token_on_scheduling true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com ci_assign_job_token_on_scheduling true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [-] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org,gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [-] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [ ] Set a milestone to the rollout issue to signal for enabling and removing the feature flag when it is stable.
- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Leave a comment on [the feature issue][main-issue] announcing estimated time when this feature flag will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [ ] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_assign_job_token_on_scheduling <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [-] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Leave a comment on [the feature issue][main-issue] announcing that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Consider cleaning up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel. Otherwise these settings may override the default enabled.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue][main-issue] to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue][main-issue] to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set ci_assign_job_token_on_scheduling false
```

title: Backend: Check Group & Project permissions for OWNER and MAINTAINER for Pipeline Authoring
description:
### Background

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/374607+ we are asked to check if there are any differences between group and project owner and maintainer's abilities. Their goal is to align the project and group permissions.

By identifying where they differ, we can announce a breaking change and align these permissions in %"16.0" 

### Outcome

Verify if there are any differences between OWNER and MAINTAINER, and if there are lets document them.

3 questions would need to be answered

- Permissions available for group OWNER and MAINTAINER? (Y/N)
- Permissions available for project OWNER and MAINTAINER? (Y/N) 
- Are group and project MAINTAINER and OWNER permissions aligned? (Y/N)

title: Webhook secret tokens leaked in webhook logs
description:
**[HackerOne report #1757999](https://hackerone.com/reports/1757999)** by `joaxcar` on 2022-11-01, assigned to @greg:

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

####  Summary

Since this issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/359989 was merged webhook secrets are hidden for maintainers of a project after they are saved. The UI and API gives no way of retrieving the secret after configuration. Just like hidden tokens in integrations. The issue states

> Use type="password" for the Secret token field input. We also have to make sure that the values are not exposed to the frontend

After the fix the input field only show a line of dots when trying to edit a webhook. But the webhook logs at the same page still contains the secret in plain text.

The docs states this about the secret

> You can specify a secret token to validate received payloads. The token is sent with the hook request in the X-Gitlab-Token HTTP header. Your webhook endpoint can check the token to verify that the request is legitimate.

This change to the input field of the UI was made intentionally to hide the secret from other maintainers (as they do not necessarily have access to the receiving service). The leaked token (LOW confidentiality) gives an unauthorized other maintainer the ability to spoof requests to the receiving server (LOW integrity). And the impacted service is the receiving service (Scope changed). This was my rating of this, feel free to edit it as see fit!

####  Steps to reproduce

1. Log in to gitlab  
2. Create a new project  
3. Go to https://gitlab.com/GROUP/PROJECT/-/hooks and configure a webhook. Make sure to add a secret  
4. Click save  
5. Scroll to the bottom of the page to the list of configured hooks.  
6. Click edit on the new hook  
7. You can now see that the secret is hidden  
8. Scroll down and click "test", a test call will be made to the hook  
9. Bellow the hook info there should now be a log entry, click the log entry  
10. Scroll to the bottom of the log page to the request headers, there is the secret in plain text

####  Impact

The UI leaks secret tokens that should not be accessible after configuration

####  What is the current *bug* behavior?

Secret token headers are shown in webhook logs

####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The secret token header should be redacted in the logs

####  Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![secret.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/c40f297a-c5a1-45ad-bad2-3aa14dd5a219/secret.png)

![token.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/55cfc65b-166d-479f-a48f-a243ec5807f7/token.png)

####  Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

####  Impact

The UI leaks secret tokens that should not be accessible after configuration, allowing unauthorised maintainers to use the token

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

* [secret.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/c40f297a-c5a1-45ad-bad2-3aa14dd5a219/secret.png)
* [token.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/55cfc65b-166d-479f-a48f-a243ec5807f7/token.png)

## How To Reproduce

Please add [reproducibility information] to this section:

1.
1.
1.

title: [ Design] Health Status for Work Items MVC
description:
## Summary

This is the ~UX issue for the Health Status for Work Items MVC. 

- Requirements: https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/9185 
- Technical Spike: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/378057
- BE: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/381898
- FE: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/381899

## Proposal

 **Figma**: [here](https://www.figma.com/file/u6AFgx87HnR367wwbMPU9Z/Health-status?node-id=3%3A66598&t=QEnzZnRyKh8qa28S-1)


#### [Health status picker](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/381892/designs/Health_status_work_item_control.png)

In both `objectives` and `key results`:

- The order of options should be: status (open/close), progress, health status, assignee, milestone, labels
- Add the `Health status` picker with `None` or `No status` (within dropdown) set as default

#### [List views](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/381892/designs/Health_status_in_list_views.png)

In both `objectives` and `key results`:

- Display the health status badge for any child that has a status assigned
   - Styling: [badge](https://design.gitlab.com/components/badge/) component, On track (success), Needs attention (warning), At risk (danger)
- The display of metadata should be consistent with the order of options: progress, health status, assignee, milestone, labels

title: No protected environment approval option available on environment index page
description:
### Summary No approval option exists on the environment index page after logging in as a approver to approve the deployment of a protected environment ### Steps to reproduce 1. Executor and Approver groups was invited into project to be deployed - OperatorGroup: Executors of the deployment to the protected environment - QA tester: Approvers for the deployment - Security Group: Approvers for the deployment ![image](/uploads/f6756af4f7be2b7946f5bef3c583b287/image.png) 2. Multiple approval rules was configured as below. ``` { "name": "production", "deploy_access_levels": [ { "access_level": null, "access_level_description": "OperatorGroup", "user_id": null, "group_id": 19, "id": 8, "group_inheritance_type": 0 } ], "required_approval_count": 0, "approval_rules": [ { "id": 9, "user_id": null, "group_id": 17, "access_level": null, "access_level_description": "QA tester", "required_approvals": 1, "group_inheritance_type": 0 }, { "id": 10, "user_id": null, "group_id": 18, "access_level": null, "access_level_description": "Security Group", "required_approvals": 1, "group_inheritance_type": 0 } ] } ``` 3. As the approver, i was directed to the environment index page and click 'approval options' but the approve button is missing. ![image](/uploads/045272bb515ea45a2b86b47b5ec015fa/image.png) ![image](/uploads/9e8d7ac3cd925100bb6c2d0fd723b9d0/image.png) ### Example Project I can't create example project on GitLab.com as this requires multiple accounts, this was reproduced on my self-managed instance and a shared over a zoom session was with @shinya.maeda ### What is the current *bug* behavior? Approve button is missing on environment index page but navigating into the protected environment, the approve button is available there. ![image](/uploads/4e67c70b55e728c163c93b48b4d99edc/image.png) ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? The approve button should be available on the environment index page ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes Implement the smallest possible graphql query to fetch approval permissions on the environments page, refactoring specifically the `environment_approval.vue` component. Make sure this plays nice with the work done in gitlab-org/gitlab#23036 as well.

title: IssuesFinder performs poorly with large numbers of issue assignments / project authorizations
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

A team member reported an increase in 500 errors. When investigating further,
this was found to be due to a query timeout. It seems that large numbers of `issue_assignees`
associated with a user causes this query to enter a deep nested loop.

DB Lab: https://console.postgres.ai/shared/eb28807b-821c-41dd-8709-989693c16829

Query:

```sql
SELECT
    COUNT(*)
FROM
    "issues"
    INNER JOIN "projects" ON "projects"."id" = "issues"."project_id"
    LEFT JOIN project_features ON projects.id = project_features.project_id
WHERE
    (
        EXISTS (
            SELECT
                1
            FROM
                "project_authorizations"
            WHERE
                "project_authorizations"."user_id" = 4668781
                AND (project_authorizations.project_id = projects.id)
        )
        OR projects.visibility_level IN (0, 10, 20)
    )
    AND (
        "project_features"."issues_access_level" > 0
        OR "project_features"."issues_access_level" IS NULL
    )
    AND ("issues"."state_id" IN (1))
    AND EXISTS (
        SELECT
            "issue_assignees".*
        FROM
            "issue_assignees"
        WHERE
            "issue_assignees"."user_id" = 4668781
            AND (issue_id = issues.id)
    )
    AND "projects"."archived" = FALSE
```

Explain plan:

```sql
 Aggregate  (cost=43209.51..43209.52 rows=1 width=8) (actual time=8896.062..8907.433 rows=1 loops=1)
   Buffers: shared hit=27747 read=20931 dirtied=764
   I/O Timings: read=25995.680 write=0.000
```

title: Add new message for retried manual job
description:
# Proposal

A retried manual job currently has the same message as an unplayed manual job: `This job requires manual intervention to start. Before starting this job, you can add variables below for last-minute configuration changes.`

![image](/uploads/2777b43b00545f3684c7abeebec37bce/image.png)

This might be confusing for users since it implies that the job was never started. We need a new message that references that the job has already been run.

# Proposed solution

Add the message `This job can be run again. Before running this job again, you can modify its variables below.` for manual jobs that are retryable.

title: Verify the partition detaching works as expected for `security_findings` table
description:
## Why are we doing this work

We've implemented the retention period for the `security_findings` table by #351524+ but we have to wait at least 3 months to verify that detaching the redundant partitions is working as expected on production, therefore, we will be checking if the first partition(`security_findings_1`) has already been detached successfully.

**Scheduled to work after the 8th of February 2023.**

## Relevant links

- #351524+

## Implementation plan

- Run the following command on postgres.ai to see existing partitions of the `security_findings` table; `\\\\d+ security_findings`
- If `security_findings_1` is not listed in partitions, write a comment that it does not exist and close this issue :tada:
- If `security_findings_1` still exists, create an issue to investigate why it still exists and inform the `@gitlab-org/govern/threat-insights-backend-team`

title: Update translations levels (December 2022)
description:
## Introduction

With the implementation of the feature to show the [translation coverage](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328430) in the language selection dropdown, the translation levels need to be updated on a monthly cadence.

## Proposal

Once the monthly merge of the new translations is complete, update the translation levels [data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/i18n.rb#L43) from Crowdin.

## Documentation

* https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/i18n/merging_translations.html#manually-update-the-translation-levels

#### ToDo

* [x] After cloning: update Title, set Milestone, Due date (15th), Related to previous month's issue.
* [x] After the 1st of the month: assign to yourself, set ~2526320
* [x] Complete the [regular monthly merge](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3571) of translations from Crowdin.
* [x] Get the translation levels (% approved words) from [Crowdin](https://crowdin.com/project/gitlab-ee).
* [x] Create an MR to update the translation levels [data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/i18n.rb#L43).
* [x] Associate that MR to this issue.
* [x] Complete the MR.
* [x] When done, clone [this template issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/349815) for the next milestone.

epic.title: Regular i18n translation merges

title: Update to default branch on project via GUI or API fails to take affect
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "type::bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=type::bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->

When attempting to modify the default branch on a project, let's say, from `main` to `development` and saving the changes via the GUI, the GUI reports `Project settings were successfully updated`, but upon page refresh the default branch is still set to `main`.

Using the Projects API to attempt the change returns a `200` code but the change is not reflected either.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

We have not been able to recreate this behavior, but it is affecting a specific GitLab.com project when following these steps:

1. Open the project via the GUI.
2. Go into `Settings -> Repository`.
3. Expand the `Branch defaults` section.
4. Select the new default branch from the dropdown (`development` in this case).
5. Click `Save changes`.
6. Refresh the page and notice the default branch is still set to the previous value instead of `development`.

### Example Project

<!-- If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic 
behavior, and link to it here in the bug report. If you are using an older version of GitLab, this 
will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version. -->

Unable to recreate.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->

The default branch is still set to the previous value.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

<!-- Describe what you should see instead. -->

The default branch is properly updated.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

<!-- Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code
 as it's tough to read otherwise. -->

When the affected user clicks on `Save changes` and attempts to update the default branch, the following call to the `Projects::Settings::RepositoryController` is logged by GitLab which properly displays the desired change, in the `production_json` log:

```json
"params": [
        {
          "key": "_method",
          "value": "put"
        },
        {
          "key": "authenticity_token",
          "value": "[FILTERED]"
        },
        {
          "key": "update_section",
          "value": "js-issue-settings"
        },
        {
          "value": "{\"default_branch\"=>\"development\", \"autoclose_referenced_issues\"=>\"1\", \"issue_branch_template\"=>\"\"}",
          "key": "project"
        },
        {
          "key": "namespace_id",
          "value": "[REDACTED]"
        },
        {
          "value": "[REDACTED]",
          "key": "project_id"
        }
      ]
```

The `audit_json` log however displays the following message, showing that the default branch was not changed:

```
Default branch changed from main to main

```

Team members with access to Kibana for GitLab.com may review the full details [here](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/b758beb0-5e29-11ed-8d37-e9a2f393ea2a).


### Output of checks

<!-- If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, uncomment below -->

This bug happens on GitLab.com
### Possible fixes

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->

A [recent change](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/102265) to the default branch setting's location may be related.
